results.title: Spotlights: Ana Kokkinos
results.brief_description: An Australian film and TV director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Kokkinos has directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009).

constellations_primary.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_primary.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.
description_for_label: Ana Kokkinos is an Australian film and television director and screenwriter of Greek descent born in Melbourne. Prior to her career in film, she worked as an industrial lawyer. Kokkinos has since directed three feature-length films and two short films including Head On (1998), The Book of Revelation (2006) and Blessed (2009). Here she discusses diversity, particularly in relation to class and queerness.

results.title: Raumlichtkunst
results.credit_line:
Oskar Fischinger

Three-screen installation

Reconstruction by Center for Visual Music, USA
results.brief_description: Oskar Fischinger’s Raumlichtkunst is one of the first multimedia projections ever made. Using film projectors, colour filters and slides, Fischinger staged multi-screen film events that were first shown in Germany around 1926 and reconstructed by the Center for Visual Music (CVM) in Los Angeles.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

results.description:
This exhibition presents one of the first multimedia projections ever made, Oskar Fischinger’s Raumlichtkunst, a reconstruction of his multiple-screen film events, first shown in Germany in 1926, and restored by the Center for Visual Music (CVM) in Los Angeles.  Working with Fischinger’s original 1920s nitrate film, CVM restored the 35mm film via traditional photochemical processes, transferred it to HD, digitally restored the colour, and reconstructed this three-screen version of his performances. Originally accompanied by live avant-garde percussion, CVM chose two versions of ‘Double Music’ by John Cage and Lou Harrison, and ‘Ionisation’ by Edgard Varèse.

CVM’s Film Restoration was supported by an Avant-Garde Masters Grant funded by The Film Foundation, administered by The National Film Preservation Foundation

Curator/archivist Cindy Keefer

Music supervisor Richard Brown, Ph.D.

Thanks to Barbara Fischinger, Cinemaculture, Film Technology, Co., Hollywood, and William Moritz

Raumlichtkunst is generously supported by Naomi Milgrom AC and the Naomi Milgrom Foundation. Through this important partnership, we will commission and present major works across an international moving image art series, building on ACMI and Naomi Milgrom AC’s experience of supporting, commissioning and presenting leading artists working with the moving image globally.
description_for_label:
This exhibition presents one of the first multimedia projections ever made, Oskar Fischinger’s Raumlichtkunst, a reconstruction of his multiple-screen film events, first shown in Germany in 1926, and restored by the Center for Visual Music (CVM) in Los Angeles.  Working with Fischinger’s original 1920s nitrate film, CVM restored the 35mm film via traditional photochemical processes, transferred it to HD, digitally restored the colour, and reconstructed this three-screen version of his performances. Originally accompanied by live avant-garde percussion, CVM chose two versions of ‘Double Music’ by John Cage and Lou Harrison, and ‘Ionisation’ by Edgard Varèse.

CVM’s Film Restoration was supported by an Avant-Garde Masters Grant funded by The Film Foundation, administered by The National Film Preservation Foundation

Curator/archivist Cindy Keefer

Music supervisor Richard Brown, Ph.D.

Thanks to Barbara Fischinger, Cinemaculture, Film Technology, Co., Hollywood, and William Moritz

Raumlichtkunst is generously supported by Naomi Milgrom AC and the Naomi Milgrom Foundation. Through this important partnership, we will commission and present major works across an international moving image art series, building on ACMI and Naomi Milgrom AC’s experience of supporting, commissioning and presenting leading artists working with the moving image globally.

results.title: [Remix: Transport]
results.brief_description: This short film is a remix of archival footage from the ACMI Collection, focusing on public transport in Victoria. The remix contains footage of trams, trains, Flinders Street Station and city streets in Melbourne.
results.description: This short film is a remix of archival footage from the ACMI Collection, focusing on public transport in Victoria. The remix contains footage of trams, trains, Flinders Street Station and city streets in Melbourne.
description_for_label: This short film is a remix of archival footage from the ACMI Collection, focusing on public transport in Victoria. The remix contains footage of trams, trains, Flinders Street Station and city streets in Melbourne.

results.title: The Family Law exhibition footage
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.
results.description:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.
description_for_label:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

results.title: The Family Law
results.brief_description: Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a unique perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

constellations_primary.name: The Family Law
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of Asian representation on screens around the world that delves into TV, cinema, documentaries and Disney princesses.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

constellations_other.name: Tony Ayres
constellations_other.description: Charts the acclaimed career of Tony Ayres through his work in film and TV.

results.description:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

“I really do think that when you’re a storyteller, and that’s what the media and the arts are, you do have a responsibility to tell the stories and a full range and diversity of what those stories actually are out there.” - Benjamin Law
description_for_label:
Fourteen-year-old Benjamin Law is desperate to win his school’s talent show. Not only must he chart a course to high-school stardom, but he also needs to navigate all the issues of Australian adolescence: embarrassing parents, bickering siblings, school bullies, best friends and his own sexuality.

Based on Benjamin Law’s 2010 book of the same name, The Family Law was the first Australian TV show to focus on an Asian Australian family. While it explores familiar stories about an everyday family, it offers a uniquely Asian Australian perspective on what it means to be Australian today.

“I really do think that when you’re a storyteller, and that’s what the media and the arts are, you do have a responsibility to tell the stories and a full range and diversity of what those stories actually are out there.” - Benjamin Law
